Game

Class Item

  • java.lang.Object
    • Game.Item
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Food, Medicine, Toy

    public abstract class Item
extends java.lang.Object

    Abstract Item which will be inherited by Toy, Food and Medicine; as this provides the functionality of an item. Items can be used to heal, feed or to be used to play with pets. Every item has an associated name, cost, description, restore value, 'restore type', flag to determine an item is stackable/consumable and number of uses (i.e. durability).

    If the flag isStackable is true, then the item can be stacked and is a consumable. A consumable item can not be broken by misbehaving pets and can always be added to inventory. Medical items and toys items are consumables. If isStackable is false, then the item is not stackable and not a consumable. Toys is a non-consumable. A non-consumable can be broken by misbehaving pets and may not always be enough room to add into the player's inventory. A player can only have one of each toy in their inventory at a time.

    Restore type is what determines if an item is a Food, Toy or Medicine object. As the Player class stores items in an ArrayList of type Item, the type of item can not be determined by the class an object was instantiated by. Hence, an integer property 'restoreType' is used to determine what type of the type of item is.

    Restore Type, their associated item type and what attribute the restoreValue affects

    1 - Medicine item, primarily restores a pet's health

    2 - Food item, primarily restores a pet's hunger and increases their weight etc.

    3 - Toy item, primarily restore's a pet happiness and drains energy etc.

    Every time an item is used, it will take durability damage. Durability is equivalent to the number of uses an item has left.

      • use

        public final java.lang.String use(Player player,
                                  Pets pet)
        An item is used, numUses property decreases. Item 'broken' and is removed from player's inventory when it runs out of uses (i.e. no durability left).
        Parameters:
        player - Player who will use the item.
        pet - Pet that the item will be used on, pets stats will be changed.
        Returns:
        Message that will be displayed the player, informing them of what happened.

      • breakItem

        public final java.lang.String breakItem(Player player)
                                 throws java.lang.RuntimeException
        When an item is 'broken' by either running out of durability/number of uses, or because of misbehaving pets, item is removed from the player's inventory.
        Parameters:
        player - Player who will lose the item from their inventory.
        Returns:
        A message informing the user if an item has been broken.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object otherItem)
        Method is used to check if two food objects are the same by comparing their names. Since all the same objects will have the same name, this single comparison is sufficient.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        otherItem - The other item this is being compared to.
        Returns:
        Returns true if they are the same item, false if they are not the same.

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Hashcode method is overridden as we needed to override the equals method. Not expected to be used in the program; comparisons between items should be only be used with equals. Hashcode uses the item's restore value as the seed for the hash code.
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object
